Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Chemical Control of Polymer/PbS Blends for PV Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Collaborative
PI Names: Moule (Lead), Ganapathysubramanian, Ginger
Proposal Numbers: 1436273 - 1437636 - 1437016

The sun represents the most abundant potential source of pollution-free energy on earth. Solar cells for conversion of light to electricity based on organic polymers integrated into a photovoltaic (PV) device offer a potentially low-cost route for renewable electricity production if the solar energy conversion efficiency can be improved. The key to improving the efficiency of organic polymer based solar cells is to better understand the molecular arrangement of the materials within the polymer film. This project will apply novel electron microscopy tools to understand how materials processing affects the three-dimensional arrangement of materials in polymer/nanoparticle films designed for photovoltaic (PV) applications. Mixtures of low-cost lead sulfide (PbS) nanoparticles with electrically conducting polymers will be studied because these mixtures have shown recent high photovoltaic efficiency, and because these materials have high imaging contrast by electron microscopy. The electron tomography will generate three dimensional concentration maps of materials within the mixture. These maps will be used to correlate processing conditions to material arrangement within the polymer/nanoparticle film. This information will then be correlated to device performance in order to identify strategies for making better solar cells based on organic polymers. The work will be carried out by a collaborative team that will simultaneously advance the science of polymer/nanoparticle film fabrication, three dimensional electron microscope imaging, and computational analysis of the images to reveal nanoscale structure. This collaborative approach has the potential uncover the structural origin of optical and electronic properties that cannot be measured by any other technique. With respect to education and activities for broadening participation, the project will provide a diverse set of outreach and educational opportunities that include interaction with children through the Boys and Girls Scouts and 4H, public education at well attended local festivals, inclusion of research material in classes, and retention of female engineering students.

Technical Description

This project will develop and use new electron tomography tools to understand how materials processing affects the three-dimensional arrangement of materials in hybrid polymer/nanoparticle films designed for photovoltaic (PV) applications. Mixtures of low-cost lead sulfide (PbS) nanoparticles with electrically conducting polymers will be studied because these mixtures have shown recent high photovoltaic efficiency, and because these materials have high imaging contrast by electron microscopy. The electron microscopy tool is based on high-angle annular dark-field scanning electron tomography (HAADF-ET) combined with the discrete algebraic reconstruction technique (DART) to generate three-dimensional (3D) material concentration maps with resolution of less than three cubic nanometers for the hybrid organic/inorganic photovoltaic materials. Development of morphology descriptors of the 3D data, including features like the number of phases, concentration ratio in each phase, domain size, domain connectivity, tortuosity of pathways, anisotropy and domain surface area will be measured using graph-based analysis. This information will be used to correlate morphology, structural heterogeneity, and physical distribution of recombination sites in mixed organic/inorganic electronic films to optoelectronic properties and photovoltaic performance. With respect to education and activities for broadening participation, the project will provide a diverse set of outreach and educational opportunities that include interaction with children through the Boys and Girls Scouts and 4H, public education at well attended local festivals, inclusion of research material in classes, and retention of female engineering students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There is a large and worldwide research effort on new photovoltaic materials and materials processing. One major subtheme of this research is the effort to reduce the cost of photovoltaic materials by designing a photovoltaic ink that can be applied to a light and flexible substrate. All of the work in this proposal focuses on studying the morphology (meaning mixing at the nanoscale) of mixtures of polymers with nanoparticles or polymers with fullerenes. In particular, the nanoparticles tend to separate from the polymers during solution coating. Previous groups developed a two-step deposition that first mixes the polymer and nanoparticles with a coating on the nanoparticle to improve mixing and then in a second step replaces with coating with a new coating that is electronically more favorable. This second step is called ligand exchange. Our proposal was focused on understanding how ligand exchange changes the mixing between the polymer and nanoparticles using a measurement technique called electron tomography. Tomography is the process of constructing a 3D image using a series of 2D pictures and electron tomography makes the 3D images using an scanning tunneling electron microscope.

The goal of this project was to apply electron tomography to understand how materials processing, surface chemistry, and material transport affect the optical and electrical properties of mixed polymer/nanoparticle and polymer/fullerene films.  This project involves three research groups, the Moulé group at UC Davis, the Ganapathysubramanian group at Iowa State, and the Ginger group at University of Washington. Each groups is responsible for specific components of the integrated collaborative project. 

The three groups worked together to produce a series of four published research articles and one in progress. The main conclusions of the research articles are:

(1)    We studied the effect that the fullerene size has on the mixing morphology with the polymer PTB7. Fullerene size has a significant effect on the mixing ratio with larger fullerenes mixing more poorly with the polymer for most champion polymers. We also showed that the common solvent additive 1,8 diodooctane can co-crystalize with the fullerene, making the materials phase separate and the device fail.

(2)    We studied the morphology of devices coated using a spin coater vs a blade coater, where the blade coater is better for industrial scale-up. We showed that the blade coated devices had more mixed phase and less connection between pure phases in device layers, which explains poorer performance in blade coated samples.

(3)    We studied the effect of ligand exchange on polymer/nanoparticle films. We found that if the second ligand is much smaller than the first, that the film is damaged by uneven shrinkage and shows defects on the 10’s to 1000’s of nm length scale. We also showed that using a three step fabrication with ligand exchange in solution before in the film results in a film that does now shrink during ligand exchange and thus has a better photovoltaic performance.

The broader impact of this award was seen in training of new professionals in photovoltaic and microscopy. All trained scientists and engineered got desired jobs quickly out of school.

The second broader impact came in the development of a 4H curriculum for chemistry experiments. A large number of kids were exposed to fundamental chemistry ideas in the context of fun. The 4H curriculum was expanded for use in a Girlscout troop and for an elementary school science night. The participating graduate students helped guide the kids in experiments and in so doing learned how to communicate science to a broader audience.
